Fields.DialogueText: Ah, that never gets old. Wish I could replace all the water in the world with delicious Tuaca!

Fields.MenuText: I see you're still enjoying yourself.
I figured you would've finished that off by now.
You're still drunk?

Fields.DialogueText: How can one not when they have the nectar of the gods accompanying them?
Nope, still going strong... I think...
I'm not stiiiiiiill drunk. I'm drunk again. See the difference?
What? Noooo, I'm out? No! Capitano, we need to make a stop. We need more Tuaca!
No, I think it's time to cut you off for a while. You're acting like a lush.
You trying to start something? Don't make me pull the trigger.
Uh, Camicia, you're aiming at the ocean.
I know that!
Phew, I think the waves are making me dizzy. I need to sit down.
*ALARM*
Oh, we've got Morganas headed this direction, Capitano! Can you hear that? No time to sit down, we need to fight!
Good thinking, Camicia. Let's go to work.
You're so smart, I was just thinking that.
Well, I guess it's good to know that, even drunk, Camicia still hungers for the battle.
@BATTLE
Hey, Camicia, how are you feeling?
Shut up.
I'm sorry?
Shut. Up.

Fields.MenuText: I just wanted to know if you were feeling any better.
I was just going to ask if you could spare a cigarette.
You can cut the attitude. I am still your captain.

Fields.DialogueText: No. Now shut up.
I would never spare a cigarette! Ugh, don't make me raise my voice. It hurts.
Excuse me, Capitano. I meant to say, shut up, please.
Just leave me alone.
Hangovers are the worst, aren't they?
Uhhhh.
It would really be horrible if the alarms went off right about now, huh?
*evil glare*
...It would be soooo horrible.
Are you trying to make me angry?
Captain, we're picking up Morganas to the west.
Well, why didn't you just sound the alarm?
Camicia Nera asked us not to.
I'm always thinking ahead, Capitano. We've got a fight on our hands! Tell everyone to get in position.
... As quietly as possible.
@BATTLE
I'm sick of patrolling, Capitano. I demand we go on a hunt.
A hunt? What are you talking about?
It's about time we track down some other worthy foes. Like the beasts we fell while we were playing bodyguard.

Fields.MenuText: You mean the beasts that nearly ripped us in two?
That's not the worst idea in the world. The Morganas have been few and far between recently.
Patrolling is an important duty, Camicia. It's integral to the war effort.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, those ones. The ones we defeated in glorious victory. It was exhilarating.
I'm glad you agree. A climactic battle is exactly what we need.
I'm not arguing that, Capitano. I'm just saying we should look for a foul beast while we're patrolling.
Now, come on. Tell the truth. Have you heard word of any especially terrifying Morganas in nearby waters?
Not that I know of, but I can put some feelers out. See if there are any urgent requests for aid.
That's all I ask, Capitano. Oh, and we have some company.
What?
*ALARM*
Oh, that kind of company.
@BATTLE
Camicia, a word?
What is it? It better be important. I was about to get some practice at the shooting range.

Fields.MenuText: It's important. I think you'll like what you're about to hear.
Maybe this can wait. Lord knows you could use the practice.
Why are you going to the shooting range? You're a wonderful shot.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh? Is this about a big battle somewhere on the horizon?
Watch what you say, or I may just practice on a certain capitano.
Stop with the boot licking.
What's so important?
A contact of mine in France told me about a horde of Morganas that have been repeatedly attacking a port town.
And Command's given us permission to investigate.
A whole horde, huh? Seems like we're heading to France then.
*ALARM*
Later rather than sooner, apparently.
A few annoyances won't take us long to dispatch. Besides, it's much better practice than the shooting range.
@BATTLE
That...doesn't look like France.

Fields.MenuText: Nope, I'm pretty sure that's France. Geography was never my best subject, though.
Nice observation. Thanks for your tremendous insight.
You're right, it's not France. We'll get there soon enough.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I know my coastlines. And this isn't France. First clue, no Morganas.
Cut the sarcasm. It's annoying.
You say that, and yet we're still here, and not there.
No need to bite my head off, Camicia. We're just going to make a short stop for supplies. You understand that, right?
Obviously. It doesn't mean I have to be happy about it.
Wouldn't you rather face a horde of Morganas with extra ammunition in hand?
You keep saying things like that. Do you have something against my aim? I'm a fine shot!
I know you are, I...
*ALARM*
We can use what ammunition we have left to take care of those Morganas to the north.
We'll have plenty ammo left over.
...I'll believe it when I see it.
Did you say something, Capitano?!
Hey, hey, point that thing somewhere else.
I really better. My trigger finger is starting to itch.
@BATTLE
There is one good thing about resupplying, I suppose.
And what's that?
A new carton of cigarettes. I hadn't even noticed, but I was running low.

Fields.MenuText: I'm starting to think you might have a problem.
Lucky you then. Told you it was it a good idea to stop here.
Did they have that rare brand of yours?

Fields.DialogueText: A problem? The only problem I have is how expensive these are by the carton.
Yeah, you do have one of those every once in a while.
Surprisingly, yes. It's a good thing too, because I doubt I'll be able to find any in France.
You should get some more of that Tuaca too. We might need to celebrate after this.
Eh, I don't think so.
Why not? I thought it was your favorite.
Oh, it is, but my head is still woozy from the last time I had it. I think I need a little more time before I get that drunk again.
Captain, we're fully stocked and the rest of the crew has come back on board.
Thank you, officer, that will be all.
Yes, Captain.
Time to head towards battle? Finally?
Seems like it. Before long, that French port town will be completely covered in a blanket of cigarette smoke.
You're really less funny than you think you are.
@BATTLE
Okay, I'm starting to get a little worried.
What's wrong with you? You're shaking!
You know how bad it is out there, right? Rain and wind that could knock over a house?
Yeah, that's why we're down here.
Well, before I left, I saw Camicia Nera, and she was just leisurely strolling on the deck, wind whipping her clothes all over, a damp cigarette in her mouth. It was like she didn't care.

Fields.MenuText: So she didn't give a damn about the storm? Not exactly a surprise.
Nothing will stop her from smoking her cigarettes.
Still stalking Camicia, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, hey, Captain.
Oh, hey, Captain.
Oh, hey, Captain.
Anyway, what worried you?
Oh, right. So Camicia was just strolling about in the storm, and she was trying to light her cigarette.
Yeah, right. No spark would catch under all that rain.
Exactly, that's what I thought. Until... she lit it.
What?
I know.
What's going on over here?
Camicia, is that a... wet cigarette?
I guess it's a little damp. I'm not complaining; it works just fine.
See?
I came down to let you know that I sense some Morganas nearby. I was thinking we could make a small detour to deal with them.
Sounds like a plan.
Okay, folks - get to work.
Yes, Captain!
@BATTLE
You're right, it's pretty much par for the course with her.
Yeah, I noticed. She screamed at me and a few of the other guys the last time she was running low. Like we could do anything about it.
I'm not stalking her. Just appreciating from a distance. No charges have been filed.
Still out here, huh?
Where else would I be?

Fields.MenuText: Your room, the mess hall, the head. A number of places, really.
The storm really doesn't bother you at all?
I guess that makes it easy to find you.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, right now, I'm here. Keeping watch while the rest of you cower from the storm.
I don't give a damn about a little rain. Though my cigarette isn't exactly a fan.
If we really needed to speak, I'd find you.
You can at least let me get you a coat or something. Just looking at you is making me shiver.
Keep your coat. It sounds like you need it more than I do.
You know, it doesn't make you weak to accept a little help.
I know that. And when I need help, I'm more than happy to accept it. Right now, though, I'm good.
Okay, if you're sure.
I am. I'm also sure there's a small group of Morganas closer than I'm comfortable with.
The alarm hasn't sounded.
They're taking advantage of the storm.
Isn't that your move?
Yes. Now, let's show them why I'm the best at it.
@BATTLE
Looks like we're finally out of the storm.
It did last a little longer than we're used to, didn't it?

Fields.MenuText: It must've known you were on board.
The sea can be harsh.
I hardly noticed, honestly. Then again, I wasn't walking around in it the whole time.

Fields.DialogueText: Mhmmmm, I get it, very funny.
The storm wasn't that bad. I hardly saw any lightning.
I wasn't going to let the storm change my daily routine.
Do we have an ETA?
Actually, the port town should be in sight soon enough.
I'll keep an eye on the horizon, then.
Just don't forget to keep an eye out for any approaching Morganas too.
Obviously. Actually, I think we might have company.
*ALARM*
Yup, we definitely have company.
Out of the storm and into the firefight.
Just the way I like it.
@BATTLE
Capitano, our destination is in sight.

Fields.MenuText: That's great.
That's horrible.
How's it look?

Fields.DialogueText: Not exactly, I think it's about to be under attack.
Did somebody already tell you?
Fortified. I think they're anticipating an attack.
I'm sensing several Morganas headed straight for them. If we don't hurry, I'm not sure how much of the town will be left when we get there.
Then we should hurry.
But not too fast.
Excuse me?
If we get there after they engage, we'll be able to flank them. We'll have the advantage.
You're right... do you think the town will be able to handle a volley from that many Morganas?
With their fortifications, they should be fine. Don't worry, I've thought about this. We'll be able to take them down faster if they don't see us coming.
Okay, we'll hurry, stealthily.
@BATTLE
Tell me what? I just hate France.
You're our reinforcements?
Something like that.
I was expecting something more... well, more.
Well, we were able to take care of those Morganas off the coast pretty easily, weren't we?
Oui, but, that group was only a small fraction of the armada that has set their sights on us. They've sent twice that number before. We were lucky. All of us.

Fields.MenuText: Twice as many? That sounds... terrifying.
No matter the amount, Morganas don't scare us.
Still doubt us, huh? I guess they haven't heard the stories about you, Camicia.

Fields.DialogueText: The number doesn't matter. Not to me and my weapons, at least.
In fact, we scare Morganas.
I guess not. And I'd appreciate it if you kept those stories to yourself.
*BOOM*
Great, they're back. We appreciate that you're here to help, but we're needed in defense of the coast right now.
Very well. Know, though, that if you want to drive the Morganas away for good, we'll need to strategize together.
Maybe, but that can wait. You can come and join us, or wait in our harbor. Either way, we must go.
So, what do you think? Should we stay or join the battle?
The guns are already loaded.
@BATTLE
So that's your plan?
This is what we've come up with. Do you have something better?
Chasing down the next horde that attacks until they lead you to the rest of their Morgana compatriots is a suicide mission.
I'm sorry, I'll ask again! Do you have a better idea?
You misunderstand. I meant it's a suicide mission for you. You're not strong enough. They'd eat you alive.

Fields.MenuText: You're suggesting we do it?
You're suggesting they just sit here and take it?
You think we need to come up with a better plan?

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly. They're weak, we're not. It's that simple.
No. They won't be able to take these attacks much longer.
There's no need. We already have a plan.
We'll follow the next horde that slinks away from here with their tails between their legs. Then we'll make sure every last Morgana in their lair feels our fury.
Mademoiselle! We are far from weak. We're capable of facing these Morganas on our own.
Wouldn't you rather stay here to protect your home?
You'd have to at least let us send some of our men to join you.
I don't need your men. *spit* They wouldn't be able to keep up with me anyway.
Capitaine, you must allow us to handle these Morganas. They're our problem, and we can defeat them.
Camicia won't work with you. So the way I see it, one of our forces will chase down the Morganas, and the other will stay here to defend the port.
You know where I belong, Capitano.
*ALARM*
I'll think about this, but right now, Captain, you need to get back to your ship. More Morganas are headed this direction.
I'll see you on the battlefield.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Another raid already?

Fields.MenuText: Too much for you?
I guess they're stepping up their game.
You know you love it.

Fields.DialogueText: Not yet, but I'll keep you updated.
They must realize they'll need to if they want to take me down.
Well, we're winning, so yes.
*BOOM*
Let's hurry.
@BATTLE
What's with that face?
The French ship started without us.
And that makes you angry?
I don't enjoy the company of people like that. That capitano thinks he and his men are strong. Yet without me, they'd all be dead by now.
You're right, you're the reason they're alive. Let's focus on that and make sure your gun stays aimed the Morganas.
*sigh*
Have you made a decision yet?
We've been a little busy fighting off these attacks.
Yes, well, these attacks will continue until you make a decision.
I know.
Look, I couldn't care less about this town or these people, but right now, we're standing between them and a massive amount of Morganas.
If you would just let me, I could drive away the entirety of them, but for some reason, you haven't given me the order. What's keeping you?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure you're strong enough.
They could be too dangerous. It's risky.
It'd be easier if we could all work together.

Fields.DialogueText: Then you clearly haven't been paying attention.
Risk is just a word people like you use as an excuse. I don't give a damn about your "risk."
You mean with these weaklings? We'd all die if I had to worry about protecting them.
All right, I've made my decision.
Finally.
I'll call a meeting so we can discuss the matter in full.
Just tell me now.
*ALARM*
Worry less about my decision and more about the Morganas knocking on our front door.
You're one lucky bastard. I guess I'll wait for this meeting.
@BATTLE
I assume, since you made me come all this way, you've come to a decision.
I have.
So you will stay here and guard in our stead while we defeat the Morgana force?
We'll be the ones destroying the Morganas. But feel free to wait here and bake us some croissants while you wait for us to come back.
Camicia, that's enough. We'll be staying here for protection while the French forces attack the Morganas.
What?!
Thank you, Capitaine. My men and I greatly appreciate this. I have to hurry back and prepare them.
Good luck, and don't underestimate them.
We'll return victorious.
What was that? Why did you side with that fool?

Fields.MenuText: I didn't side with anyone. We're all on the same side.
He really wanted to go. I couldn't say no.
The French captain and his men know these waters better than we do. That gives them an advantage we lack.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, well this part "our" side feels a little lonely.
And yet you can say no to me?
Maybe so. But I still disagree with your decision.
*ALARM*
I guess the Morganas are as angry as I am.
You can yell at me later. We have Morganas to fight.
@BATTLE
It's later.
What?
You said I could yell at you later. So now I'm yelling!

Fields.MenuText: At least shut the door first.
Can I remind you that I'm your captain?
Why are you so angry?

Fields.DialogueText: No, I want the rest of the crew to hear my wrath.
Can I remind you that I don't give a rat's ass right now?
You couldn't have asked a dumber question.
They have the numbers and know these waters, so they have a better chance at success. It was as simple as that.
They don't have me.
Why are you in such a hurry to run head first into such an unbalanced battle?
I belong on the battlefield. Unbalanced or not, you can't keep me here, shackled to a bed, making lunch and rocking the baby to sleep!
I'm actually speechless.
I... you... I've yelled enough for now. Leave me alone.
You came in here--
*SLAM*
That escalated.
*ALARM*
They keep attacking. I hope the French forces are ready soon. If we stay here much longer, Camicia might tear off my head.
@BATTLE
Another Morgana raiding party!
@BATTLE
Are we clear on the plan?
Yes, we chase them off and then we let the French buffoons follow them back to their hideout. It's not the most complicated plan.
No, but that means we can't defeat them too quickly.
What? You want me to go easy on the Morganas?
Just at first.
No.

Fields.MenuText: Consider it an order.
Think of it like you're hustling them. Luring them into a false sense of security.
... Please?

Fields.DialogueText: You can take your order and shove it, Capitano.
That does sound more appealing...
Really? You do know it's not really a magic word, right?
I'll do it, but not because you told me to. Because I think it'll be a challenge not to kill them immediately.
Whatever works for you. Now let's go.
Did you see her?
Did you hear her?
I knew it was coming.
You guys talking about Camicia?
Yeah, she's been pacing a ditch into the deck since that little "conversation" of yours.
Yeah, I heard her muttering some pretty nasty stuff about you under her breath.

Fields.MenuText: I think I'm better off not asking specifics.
Nothing too bad, right?
Well, she's not the only one who's angry.

Fields.DialogueText: You're probably right.
Oh, you'd be surprised. I mean, I knew she was a sailor, but she's got quite a colorful vocabulary.
In a fight between you and Camicia Nera, I hate to say it, but I'm putting my money on her every time.
Any suggestions on what I should do? You know, to make sure she doesn't tear out my heart in the middle of the night?
*ALARM*
Don't make her angry?
A little late for that. I'll just worry about the Morganas for now. They're less scary than Camicia in one of her moods.
@BATTLE
Same.
I'd double down.
Camicia, can we talk?
‘zat you, Catpin? Heheh, I mean, Capitano?
Are you okay?
I'm great. I'm fantastic. Come. Join me in my greatness.
Whoa, this place is a wreck.
I might've gotten a little fussy and broken a chair or three. You know me.
Is that Tuaca?
Tuaca! My favorite. The crew couldn't find any of my cigarettes in town, but they did scrounge up a bottle of the best drink in the whole world. Want one?

Fields.MenuText: Sure, I guess.
No, you keep it, it's your favorite, after all.
I have to say, day drinking is a nice color on you.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, go grab a glass, I can't just pour it in your hands... I mean I could, actually...
You're right about that. If I were on a desert island, this is the one thing... no, I'd want my cigarettes, too... and my guns, and... well, I'd want a lot of things.
It's not day, Capitano. Or wait, is it? How long have I been here?
Oh, look at that, we've reached the bottom of the bottle. Looks like drinky time is over for us.
I never even had a glass.
Semantics! I need more Tuaca!
*ALARM*
Oooh, I know that sound. We've gotta kick some butt and rustle up some awesome!
What?
Come on! Morgana fighting time!
@BATTLE
Hey, Camicia, how you doing? Tuaca still keeping you in a good mood?
Battle sobers me up quickly.
I see that. So is this you still being angry, or is this you having a hangover?
Can't it be both?

Fields.MenuText: You can't stay mad at me forever.
Would a bottle of Tuaca help smooth things over?
Knowing you, yes.

Fields.DialogueText: I can certainly try.
Depends... do you have one on you?
Then If you know the answer, don't ask the question.
Is there anything I can do to make this up to you?
Captain, Camicia Nera, we've got a ship approaching.
More Morganas?
No, they appear to be French vessels.
Are they being followed.
Save your breath, I'm sensing a handful of Morganas on their tail. If we don't meet them halfway, they'll catch up with them.
Sound the alarm.
Yes, Captain.
This isn't a good sign.
I see an "I told you so" coming your way in the future, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Then no.
What happened?
Their numbers were more than we anticipated. We put up a good fight, but our only option was to retreat.
Like a coward.
... You're one to talk.
How many were there?
Too many. We didn't have much time to count.
Capitano, we can take them.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure?
You think we can take that many Morganas on our own?
Yeah, and then we'll use an underwater volcano to sail straight into heaven.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm positive.
I think I could destroy a hundred Morganas on my own.
I'm not saying we're ready to fight God, I'm just suggesting we crush a few measly Morganas.
Besides, it's not like we have many other options. Do we?
You and your men will stay here and drive off any and all approaching Morganas. And we'll finish off the main force.
If we couldn't, what makes you think you can?
I'm not sure that I can, but I know that she can.
Damn straight. Now be a good little house husband and have a pie ready for me when I get back.
*glare*
@BATTLE
So this is what scared off those imbeciles.

Fields.MenuText: I can see why. This cove is packed with Morganas.
Still confident? That's a whole lot of ugly.
We've got this. Let's be quick so we're not late for pie.

Fields.DialogueText: It'll be like shooting fish in a barrel.
Soon enough, it'll be a whole lot of destruction.
Heh, I hope he bakes better than he fights.
So how are we doing this? They haven't seemed to notice us yet.
Usually, I'd want to look for a way in unseen, but I can already tell there isn't one. The direct approach is what we've got.
... We're going to die.
I won't let that happen. I can't die this early. We've still got a whole war ahead of us.
You say that like you're looking forward to it.
Maybe I am. But right now, I'm looking most forward to this massive battle ahead of us. Let's go, I can't take it anymore.
Okay, just don't be too reckless.
No promises!
@BATTLE
They're still coming! Everyone, keep your head in the fight! No time to rest!
*BOOM*

Fields.MenuText: Still think we've got this?
We're winning, I can already tell.
We should run, right?!

Fields.DialogueText: Now more than ever. Can't you see? They're quaking in their figurative boots!
You and me both. It won't be long now before they're nothing but scrap!
Run? Don't make me laugh! I can go on like this for days!
Here they come! Prepare yourselves!
@BATTLE
That's... all of them... right?
Yeah. I think we can finally breathe easy.
I really need a smoke right now.
You already have one.
You can never have enough!
You're smoking two at once again? That's got to be a waste.
Mmmmm, feels so good.
Whatever, let's just head back.
In victory!
You did it? How-- how is that even possible?! There were countless Morganas waiting for us!
Well, I guess the Italian school system has a better math program. I was able to count them just fine.

Fields.MenuText: Ohhh, ouch. Do you need some ice for that burn?
Easy, Camicia. The Morganas were surely still recovering after their fight with the French ships. They weren't prepared for us.
The battle's over. Can't we all just get along?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure he can take an insult or two, Capitano. He's probably used to it, at this point.
*sigh* I suppose you're right. My apologies.
Yes, I suppose we should be getting along. We just won an incredible battle, let's not start another one amongst ourselves.
I just... I just can't believe that you're so powerful...
That sort of talk will go straight to Camicia's head.
You know it will!
Moving along, the town should be safe now. Under your watchful eye, Captain, I'm sure all will be well.
I appreciate the vote of confidence. We'll have to work on becoming stronger, so we're better able to face whatever threat comes our way next.
Sounds like a good idea. But in case you're ever in need of help again, know that you can always move to the kitchen and make us real fighters some lunch.
*ALARM*
Okay, that alarm means it's time to stop badmouthing our friends, Camicia.
Whatever, I've got some Morganas to badmouth.
I should return to my vessel. Thank you again... we'd be dead without you.
Of course. Despite Camicia's insults, we're allies. If you need us, we'll be there.
I'll remember that. Now, let's fight these Morganas. We need to reclaim some small part of our dignity.
@BATTLE
Hey, Camicia...
What is it? What's with the serious face?
I... wanted to ask about something you said earlier.
*sigh* I was worried you'd bring this up. You're talking about the whole "baby rocking and lunch making" thing, right?

Fields.MenuText: No, I was talking about the other thing you said out of the blue.
It seems like something we should talk about.
I didn't want to mention it earlier, because you were so angry before. But you're not any more, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be sarcastic right now, especially if you actually want to talk about this.
I'm not entirely sure that it is, I mean... not any more.
No... I worked out a lot of my anger in that fight. It felt good to get it all out.
Look, I'll just lay it all out really fast. I hate the idea that women belong on the sidelines while men do all the dangerous work.
It's bullshit. Something like that would be torture for a woman like me. And I'm sure I'm not the only one who feels this way.
I would never put you on the sidelines, Camicia.
I know. Now, that's part of the reason I'm not mad. I... I want to be seen as a warrior, not someone that needs to be protected.
Trust me, Camicia. I know that we'll protect each other.
Thank you, Capitano. You know, there's only one thing that could make this better.
Tuaca?
You read my mind! Where did you get that?
I picked it up a while ago. I've been saving it for a special occasion.
*ALARM*
Well, save it for after the battle. I want to earn it!
It'll be right here for you.
On second thought. Toss it here... I can multitask.
@BATTLE
... I honestly wonder if you shoot better when you're drinking.
Come on, Capitano. This *is* the good stuff.
